samples.question: However, I do also think that it depends on the motivation.
samples.transcript: Because a child that learns, for example, English in school, but does not really want to learn it only because it is part of the curriculum, will probably not learn it faster than an adult who is really interested in learning it because they want to move abroad and need it for their job or also their studies.
samples.transcript_original: Because a child that learns, um, for example, English in school, but doesn't really want to learn it only because it's part of the curriculum, will probably not learn it faster than an adult who's really interested in learning it because they want to move abroad and need it for their job or also their studies.

samples.question: So at what age do you think that children should start learning a foreign language?
samples.transcript: Probably the younger the better. But I think if I had to put an age, I would say when they enter school, because this is also when they, well, have to get used to having this routine of studying and have a schedule for the day.

samples.question: Do you think that journeys have become easier due to the use of navigation apps?
samples.transcript: Yes, a lot. I still remember the time when I started working in sales and visiting clients. And literally having the map on my knee in the car and driving on the Autobahn and then looking at the map and reaching my clients and planning the tour So that was a lot of effort and time put into that and a lot of stressful driving So I personally can say yes the first navigation system first GPS system in a car was like a blessing for me Okay, and why do you think people usually embark on journeys in your country? Oh, Germans are famous to, to be tourists all around the world and like I would say as a German, unfortunately you run into Germans everywhere. I remember being in Scotland in the most northern part, very secluded area, like a little village with artists and stuff like that and we ran into a little like shop and we started, we were three guys talking in German and then someone answered in German, said, in German, hey, where are you from? And then it turned out he was from the same town as we. So you travel at the end of the world and you always meet some Germans. so traveling and experience other cultures and having a big emphasis on, like, spending valuable time in your off time.

samples.question: Do you think that this kind of, traveling has also become popular nowadays?
samples.transcript: Yes, especially, with younger people it was always popular, like, after you finished school going, like, backpacking on for like half a year or a year. Australia or, Vietnam were very popular countries here. And I think with Covid and the pandemic lockdown, we had a surge in interest in like doing like local trips and hiking trips and backpacking in Germany or close by.

samples.question: Any kind of journey that you would like to do?

So if I have a hotel and stuff like that, I need different things than I just need on a hiking tour. So there are some essentials for, for like backpacking and outdoor activities. And then you need some utility items for your daily life like cooking equipment. And, like we say, if you buy cheap, you buy twice. So some, good quality matters there. Thank you very much. Now.

samples.question: Tell me a bit about Tashkent and what it is like.
samples.transcript: Well, Tashkent is growing by lips and bounds, I would say, because of all the investment. and Tashkent is really what you could call a growing multicultural city. I see a lot of people from different backgrounds, especially in more, affluent parts of the city. but generally, yeah, it is a, it is a great city to, to be living. I enjoy living in Tashkent. Tashkent and Tashkent, I think it has a population of two or three million people at this point. I do not know the exact statistics, but from from what I can guess, that is what it is. it is quite big.

samples.question: So do you get a lot of tourists in Tashkent?
samples.transcript: Yes, especially nowadays. I am not sure if the season determines how many tourists come to Tashkent. I think our food is probably one of the best things we can offer to tourists as well as our history. so we do have a lot of tourists. I see a lot of people enjoying Tashkent Metro. and Tashkent Metro is like really famous. So when you, there is incredible architecture, you know, Soviet architecture, you can see, yeah. Interesting. Yeah. Nice.

samples.question: So tell me what do you do there?
samples.transcript: Well, I, I run a test prep center. We, we, help students prepare for the IELTS exam and SAT. But although we are focusing on the latter more, you know, next year, next academic year. So at the start of the IELTS speaking test, you get some introductory questions normally about where you live, what you do, work or study, right? Here, Djorbeck talks about the town where he is living, Tashkent, and also about a little bit about his job.

samples.question: So I would like to know what makes you happy?
samples.transcript: Well, I think happiness is a state of being and I do not think happiness is something that you preach to, you know, you get hold of. But these days, I think the things that make me happy is when I spend time with my friends and I, you know, we usually go to a sports bar and watch football. Today, hopefully we are watching Manchester City play. The FA Cup. The FA Cup. So, you know, when I spend quality time with my friends, that makes me happy. Nice.

samples.question: And as a child, what made you happy as a child?
samples.transcript: Well, as a child, you know, literally anything under the sun, I think makes you happy. it is very easy. I guess I was lucky enough to have carefree childhood. samples.question: And do you feel happy at work?
